et: Middle English {it}hawe,{/it} going back to Old English {it}haga,{/it} weak masculine noun, formally identical with {it}haga{/it} "fence, fenced enclosure, hedge" (whence Middle English {it}hawe{/it} in same sense), going back to Germanic {it}*hagan-{/it} (whence also Middle Dutch {it}hage{/it} "thornbush," {it}haghe{/it} "thornbush forming a border," Old Icelandic {it}hagi{/it} "enclosed field, pasture"), derivative of a base {it}*hag-{/it} seen also in {it}*haga-,{/it} masculine a-stem, whence Old English {it}hæg-{/it} "enclosure" (in placenames), Old High German {it}hag{/it} "palisade, enclosed land"; in {it}*hagi-,{/it} masculine i-stem, whence Old English {it}hege{/it} "hedge, fence, boundary wall" (whence Middle English {it}heye, haie,{/it} in part reflecting also Anglo-French {it}haie{/it} "hedge, fence"), Middle Low German {it}hege{/it}; in {it}*hagjō{/it} {et_link|hedge:1|hedge:1}; in {it}*hagna-,{/it} masculine a-stem, derivative with the suffix of appurtenance {it}-na-,{/it} whence Old Saxon {it}hagan{/it} "thornbush, buckthorn," Middle Dutch {it}haghen{/it} "enclosure," Old High German {it}hagan{/it} "thornbush, plants of the genera {it}Crataegus{/it} and {it}Rhamnus{/it}"; Germanic {it}hag-{/it} going back to dialectal Indo-European {it}*kag{sup}h{/sup}-{/it} "enclosure," whence also Celtic {it}*kagi̯o-{/it} (whence Welsh {it}cae{/it} "hedge, hedgerow, field," Cornish {it}ke{/it} "hedge, ditch," Old Breton {it}caiou{/it} glossing {it}munimenta{/it} "defensive works, barrier," Breton {it}kae{/it} "hedge, field") and probably Latin {it}caulae,{/it} plural only, "railing, lattice forming a barrier" (going back to {it}*kahelā{/it})

Old English {it}haga{/it} in the sense "hawthorn berry" may have been extracted from {it}hagaþorn{/it} {et_link|hawthorn|hawthorn} or an unattested compound with {it}berie{/it} {et_link|berry:1|berry:1}. Germanic {it}*hag-{/it} "enclosure," with its numerous derivative stems, appears to have been intimately connected with the thorny plants such as {it}Crataegus{/it} used to form hedges. — The northwest Indo-European etymon {it}*kag{sup}h{/sup}-{/it} "enclosure" has been associated with a verb of the same form meaning approximately "grasp, enclose," which is hypothetically the source of Umbrian {it}kukehes{/it} "you (or s/he) will reach," Oscan {it}kahad{/it} "s/he takes," as well as some of the forms of Welsh {it}cael{/it} "to get, receive" (see {it}Lexikon der indogermanischen Verben,{/it} 2. Auflage, p. 342). The {it}Lexikon{/it} shows this form as both {it}*kag{sup}h{/sup}-{/it} and {it}*ḱag{sup}h{/sup}-,{/it} as {it}*kag{sup}h{/sup}-{/it} violates an Indo-European root structure constraint (though comparable forms in a satem language are lacking); a stricter laryngealist notation would be {it}*ḱh{inf}2{/inf}g{sup}h{/sup}-.{/it} Also connected with this verb is Latin {it}cohum{/it} "hollow in the middle of a yoke"—see {et_link|inchoate|inchoate}. See also {et_link|quay|quay}.

dt: {bc}an inflamed nictitating membrane of a domesticated mammal

et: Middle English {it}howe, hawe{/it} "morbid excrescence in the eye," of uncertain origin
shortdef: nictitating membrane; especially : an inflamed nictitating membrane of a domesticated mammal

dt: often used to indicate a vocalized pause in speaking

shortdef: —often used to indicate a vocalized pause in speaking

dt.t: the administration hemmed and {wi}hawed{/wi} over the students' demands

shortdef: to utter the sound represented by haw

dt: used as a direction to turn to the left
{bc}to turn to the near or left side

et: probably from {et_link|haw:3|haw:3} used as a command to an animal
shortdef: —used as a direction to turn to the left
to turn to the near or left side

dt: {bc}to stop often and change what one is saying during speech because one is not sure of what to say or because one is trying to avoid saying something

dt.t: The question surprised her and she {it}hemmed and hawed{/it} a bit before answering.

dt: {bc}to take a long time before making a decision about what to do

dt.t: The city council {it}hemmed and hawed{/it} for a year before deciding to build the new school.

shortdef: to stop often and change what one is saying during speech because one is not sure of what to say or because one is trying to avoid saying something
to take a long time before making a decision about what to do

dt: used (as by cowboys or in imitation of cowboys) to express exuberant delight or excitement

dt.t: White-collar workers squeeze into their duds and turn into studs, hanging out in honky-tonks, affecting drawls and riding mechanical bulls. {wi}Yee-haw{/wi}!
{wi}Yeehaw{/wi}! That February issue was about Texas and I was so proud!

shortdef: —used (as by cowboys or in imitation of cowboys) to express exuberant delight or excitement
